Loan Amount and Terms  The  SDPL  adopts  the  program  cluster  approach  with  two  back-to-
back subprograms totaling $100 million. Subprogram I loan amount 
will be for $60 million and subprogram II will be processed upon the 
successful completion of subprogram I. 
 
Subprogram  I  of  SDPL  will  be  drawn  from  the  Asian  Development 
Fund,  which  will  have  a  repayment  period  of  24  years,  including  a 
grace  period  of  8  years,  and  carry  an  interest  rate  of  1.0%  per 
annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter. 
Subprogram  I  will  be  implemented  within  18  months  after  loan 
effectiveness. 
 
Subprogram  II  will  be  presented  for  Board  consideration,  based  on 
progress  in  implementing  subprogram  I.  Policy  conditions  for 
subprogram  II  are  subject  to  revision  to  reflect  the  Government’s 
achievements and changing policy environment. Subprograms II will 
be implemented within 18 months after loan effectiveness. 
 
The  program  cluster  comprises  two  programs  and  subprogram  I 
comprises two tranches. The period for implementing subprogram I 
will  be  18  months  from  loan  effectiveness.  The  first  tranche  will  be 
released  upon  compliance  with  the  first  tranche  release  conditions 
and  the  second  upon  completion  of  policy  actions  proposed  for 
second tranche release. Implementation of subprogram I is planned 
for November 2004 to May 2006. The final review for subprogram I, 
second tranche release, is expected to coincide with subprogram II 
loan fact-finding.

Risks and Assumptions  There are three principal risks in implementing the SDPL. The first is 
in  effective  coordination  and  cooperation  within  the  Government, 
both  horizontally  among  different  ministries  and  agencies 
concerned,  and  vertically  with  the  provincial  and  district  authorities. 
Consultation  and  coordination  with  the  private  sector  and  the  aid 
community  active  in  SME  development  will  also  be  required.  It  is 
expected that coordination and cooperation among all stakeholders 
will  gradually  improve  along  with  the  increased  capacity  of  the 
Agency for SME Development within the MPI, thus reducing the risk 
of overlap and inconsistencies in SME support activities.  
 
A second risk pertains to good governance of the central, provincial,
and  district  governments.  Governance  at  the  provincial  and  district 
levels is particularly important given the fact that the positive impact 
of  the  SDPL  will  be  felt  only  through  effective  implementation  of 
policies  at  the  ground  level.  These  risks  are  common  to  several

continued  to  rise.  Gross  domestic  savings  and  capital  formation  also  increased  during  the

Key Issues 

Based on the analysis of the road map and consultations with stakeholders, key issues 

11. 
for SME development in Viet Nam have been identified.  
 
12. 
Incomplete  and  Inconsistent  Business  Registration  and  Licensing  Systems.  The 
Enterprise Law of 2000 promoted business registration and significantly reduced the time, cost 
and documentation for starting a business. After the enactment of the Enterprise Law, however, 
more than 50 implementing guidelines were issued on the registration and licensing process at 
different  provincial  and  district  levels.  Also,  10  decrees  containing  provisions  contradicting  the 
Enterprise  Law  have  been  identified.  Further  complicating  the  process is  the  inconsistent  new 
provisions  for  simplified  business  registration,  with  some  provinces  not  approving  the 
establishment of businesses permitted under the law. Both business registration and licensing 
systems  are  not  unified  on  a  national  basis,  nullifying  many  of  the  benefits  of  the  Enterprise 
Law. Many SMEs still suffer from inconsistent and inefficient business registration and licensing 
systems; thus, compliance costs are increasing. 
 
13. 
Absence  of  SME  Development  Policy  and  Coordination  Framework.  Although 
important  progress  has  been  made,  the  basic  framework  to  support  SME  development  is  still 
incomplete,  in  both  policies  and  institutions.  This  lack  of  a  policy  and  coordination  framework 
has  resulted  in  contradictions  and  duplications  of  support  programs  provided  by  different 
Government ministries and agencies. It also constrains effective aid coordination. Furthermore, 
there is no specific system for collecting data on the sector for purposes of policy formulation. 
Progress  to  date  in  upgrading  the  National  Business  Information  Network  (NBIN)4  has  been 
limited, and there are currently no mechanisms to provide information to and collect information 
from SMEs.   
 
Limited  Access  to  Financial  Resources.  Viet  Nam’s  financial  sector  still  perceives 
14. 
financing for SMEs to be costly and highly risky. Hence, SMEs’ access to financial resources is 
limited  despite  the  fact  that  various  aid  agencies  have  a  number  of  credit  lines  for  the  sector.

the  costs  and  risks  related  to  giving  credit  to  SMEs.  First,  recognizing  that  offering  collateral 
remains  an  important  means  for  SMEs  to  access  credit,  the  limited  access  to  land-use  rights 
certificates  (LURCs)  for  use  as  collateral  must  be  overcome.  For  SMEs  to  better  utilize  the

Limited  Access  to  International  Markets:  Technical  Standards. Although Viet Nam 
will enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) regime and the SMEs will have greater access

opportunity.  Regardless  of  WTO’s  mandates  on  tariff  and  other  means  to  seek  trade 
liberalization,  Vietnamese  exports  need  to  conform  to  various  technical  standards  before  they

barrier to SME development.

Rationale 

29. 
There  is  a  consensus  among  the  Government,  ADB,  and  the  aid  community  on  the 
urgent need to support development of SMEs to sustain economic growth and to progressively 
reduce  the  country's  poverty  incidence.  The  traditional  approach,  which  aimed  to  encourage

underlying  distortions  and  consequently  achieved  mixed  results.  The  SDPL  focuses  on  these

30. 
Creation of an enabling business environment in Viet Nam is challenging due to features 
common  to  developing  economies  in  transition.  Many  key  policy,  legal,  and  institutional 
frameworks in support of business operations have yet to be completed. There also remains a 
policy bias for public sector entities. In selecting areas to be covered under the SDPL, priority 
was  given  to  those  assessed  to  be  (i)  significant  for  SMEs'  current  business  operations,  (ii) 
backed  by  the  Government's  commitment  to  reform  in  line  with  best  practices;  (iii)  linked  to 
ADB's past and ongoing operations; and (iv) complementary to activities of other aid agencies.  
 
31. 
Intensive discussions with Government counterparts and consultation with private sector 
stakeholders and aid agencies resulted in prioritizing SDPL objectives to (i) enhancing the policy 
and  regulatory  environment,  (ii)  improving  access  to  financial  and  physical  resources,  and  (iii) 
facilitating access to domestic and international markets.

among  various  Government  ministries  and  agencies  concerned;  (ii)  continued  policy  dialogue 
with both technical officials and decision makers of the executing and implementing agencies so

and  operationalizing  systems  in  support  of  policy  implementation;  and  (iv)  technical  inputs, 
particularly  for  the  purposes  of  institutional  capacity  building.  Furthermore,  these  measures

1. 

Improving the Current Business Registration and Licensing Systems 

36. 
The Enterprise Law of 2000 shifted the paradigm of business registration and licensing 
from  one  in  which  Government  permitted  companies  to  carry  out  certain  activities,  to  one  in 
which the companies are free to engage in all activities not expressly prohibited by law. The law 
helped  improve  fairness  and  equality  in  the  business  environment  and  institutionalized  the 
principle  that  citizens  are  entitled  to  conduct  businesses  in  accordance  with  the  law.  The 
Enterprise Law concurrently simplified licensing by abolishing 150 sublicenses and introduced a 
one-stop registration system decreasing the number of steps in registration from 20 to 3.11 
 
37. 
Keeping  business  registration  and  licensing  processes  simple  and  ensuring  consistent 
and  fair  implementation  of  the  processes  reduce  uncertainty,  risks,  and  costs  for  businesses. 
However,  recent  developments  show  some  reversals  from  earlier  measures  simplifying 
business  registration  and  licensing.  For  example,  after  the  abolition  of  a  large  number  of 
licensing  requirements,  numerous  new  requirements  have  been  issued.  To  maintain  the 
momentum  of  reform  in  the  business  registration  and  licensing  procedures,  the  SDPL  will 
address (i) numerous implementing guidelines issued by provincial authorities that have caused 
confusion  to  business  registration  officers;  (ii)  arbitrary  interpretation  and  implementation  of 
business  registration  and  licensing  at  local  levels;  and  (iii)  limited  capacity  and  resources  of 
registration offices, particularly at local levels. 
 
The  SDPL  supports  the  adoption  of  increased  uniformity  in  procedures  for  business 
38. 
registration  throughout  Viet  Nam.  It  is  expected  that  the  business  registration  system  will  be 
modernized  at  all  levels––central,  provincial,  and  district––and  based  on  NBIN  so  that  the 
registration procedure may be simplified.

Identifying a More Effective Basis for Targeting SMEs 

41. 
Official  definition  of  SMEs  provides  the  basis  for  targeting,  monitoring,  and  evaluating 
the  Government's  SME  policies.  There  is  no  globally  accepted  definition  of  SMEs  and  most 
countries  establish  their  own  definition  based  on  their  specific  economic  and  social 
circumstances.

Increasing Effective Use of Collateral 

51.  Most banks in Viet Nam rely mainly on SMEs' ability to provide security for loans due to 
SMEs'  inadequate  financial  records  and  business  planning  skills  on  one  hand,  and  the  banks' 
inexperience  and  inability  to  effectively  assess  SMEs’  credit  risks  on  the  other  hand.  Given 
SMEs’ weak asset base, their options for collateral are not many and LURCs are likely to be the 
most  valuable.  Yet  issuance  of  LURCs  (as  immovable  property)  to  SMEs  has  been  extremely 
time-consuming,  with  a  series  of  checks  that  must  be  cleared  and  requirements  for  legal

authority  to  assign  land-use  rights  and  issue  LURCs  was  given  to  local  people's  committees, 
and each adopted different procedures and requirements. The situation was further complicated 
by the lack of a single, uniform land registry system in Viet Nam.

c. 

Improving the Operational Environment for Financial Leasing 
Companies 

56. 
Financial leasing operations in Viet Nam are governed by Decree 16/2001/ND-CP (May 
2001) and Circular No. 8/2001/TT-NHNN (September 2001) issued by State Bank of Viet Nam 
(SBV). The activities of financial leasing companies (FLCs) are confined to financial leasing for 
machinery, equipment, vehicles, and other movable assets; advising clients on matters relating 
to  financial  leasing  operations;  and  other  services  related  to  financial  leasing.  Sale  and 
leaseback and syndicated lease transactions are permitted, although implementing regulations 
have  yet  to  be  issued.  Transactions  in  foreign  currency  are  subject  to  the  foreign  exchange 
control  regulations  of  SBV.  FLCs  are  permitted  to  mobilize  capital  from  short-,  medium-,  and 
long-term borrowing from credit institutions in Viet Nam and abroad; issuance of bonds with a 
term of over 1 year (subject to SBV approval); and by other means as approved by SBV. 

57. 
The  development  of  the  leasing  industry  in  Viet  Nam  is  particularly  constrained  by 
shortcomings in the legal framework that restrict both the activities and the funding mechanisms 
of FLCs. The Government recognizes that the absence of implementing regulations for sale and 
leaseback  transactions  and  syndicated  leasing  constrains  FLCs  from  offering  a  fuller  product 
range  tailored  to  market  needs.  Long-term  funding  also  presents  a  problem  for  some  FLCs, 
including subsidiaries of state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) that source all or most of their 
funds from their respective parent banks. Leasing companies have cited difficulties in attracting 
term loans of more than 1 year at viable interest rates, and relatively few have been successful 
in issuing medium- or long-term bonds. To date, no leasing company has attempted to structure 
and  sell  packages  of  their  outstanding  leases,  as  a  way  of  leveraging  additional  funds.  The 
SDPL will support the Government in revising Decree 16 and Circular No. 8 governing leasing 
activities to allow wider product ranges and sources of funding for FLCs. 

4. 

Completing  the  Legal  Framework  for  Land  to  Allow  Market-Based 
Transactions  

58.  Many SME surveys in Viet Nam point to limited access to land as the foremost constraint 
to  their  growth.14  Issues  on  SMEs’  access  to  land  revolve  around  inefficiencies  resulting  from 
inconsistencies and bias distinct to economies in transition. For example, there is a significant 
difference in the proportion of land-use rights held by SOEs compared with those held by private 
sector  SMEs.  The  economic  transformation  process  has  resulted  in  a  large  amount  of  prime 
commercial and industrial land allocated to SOEs. However, many do not take full advantage of 
the land allocated to them in their industrial or commercial activities. Much land allocated to the 
SOEs  are  left  idle  with  no  plans  for  future  use  while  the  rapidly  growing  private  SMEs  are 
suffering from lack of land for their use. Consequently, leasing idle land from SOEs has become 
the most common method used by private sector SMEs to obtain land, although subletting from 
SOEs is, in most cases, illegal. 
 
59. 
Despite  the  country’s  transition  toward  a  more  market-based  economy,  land  still  is 
considered  as  being  owned  by  “all  citizens”  and  administered  by  the  State  as  “representative 
owner.”  This  fundamental  framework  has  not  changed.  However,  the  Government  is  taking 
proactive measures to clarify the principles of land law and make them consistent for developing 
a property market in Viet Nam. Given the sensitivity of issues related to land, progress will likely 
be gradual. Nonetheless, some noteworthy measures have been taken. For example, the new

be  developed  in  accordance  with  the  urban  development  master  plan.  The  detailed  plans,  as

the  primary  vehicle  for  land  use  management  and  land  allocation  associated  with  public  and

detailed plan is normally the first step in the project development process, and is a prerequisite

VI. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

In  resolving  legal,  institutional,  and  technical  constraints  that  disadvantage  SMEs  in 
94. 
accessing  credit,  acquiring  land-use  rights,  and  achieving  regulatory  compliance,  the  SDPL 
takes  a  market-based  participatory  approach.  For  instance,  the  SDPL  acknowledges  the 
fundamental  role  of  information  for  markets  to  allocate  resources  efficiently  and  the  essential 
need  for  all  market  participants  to  have  access  to  that  same  relevant  public  information.  The 
SDPL  utilizes  the  technology  available  today  in  making  as  much  pertinent  information  as 
possible obtainable in the public domain.  
 
Collectively, the availability of information for doing business in Viet Nam is expected to 
95. 
substantially  increase,  thus  reducing  the  cost  and  risks  of  doing  business  for  all  enterprises. 
Enterprises  will  benefit  from  (i)  the  establishment  of  NBIN,  which  will  have  an  on-line  SME 
gateway  providing  information  on  procedures  to  comply  with  regulations,  Government  support 
programs  for  SMEs,  business  associations,  and  other  business  support  providers;  (ii)  the 
dissemination  for  training  of  the  simplified  SME  accounting  system  through  the  Vietnamese 
Accounting  Association;  (iii)  impartial  dissemination  of  information  on  land-use  planning  and 
zoning; and (iv) an on-line database providing information on national and international technical 
and industrial standards.  
 
96. 
The  SDPL  also  introduces  information  technology  for  collecting  and  compiling 
information  and  data  nationwide.  The  current  fragmented  database  on  business  activities  and 
land usage constrains the Government and businesses in making informed decisions. Both the 
rollout of NBIN nationwide and adoption of a single land registry aim to make available timely, 
accurate, and comprehensive information covering all of Viet Nam. Such database is part of a 
modern  infrastructure  required  for  efficient  functioning  of  markets  and  may  be  considered  as 
public goods that help achieve transactional efficiencies.  
 
97. 
Adopting  simple  and  uniform  systems  and  administrative  procedures  is  the  basic 
principle  that  guides  the  SDPL.  Simple  and  uniform  systems  and  administrative  procedures 
have  the  merit  of  avoiding  confusion,  arbitrariness,  and  rent-seeking  behavior  in  delivering 
public  services,  particularly  at  the  provincial  and  district levels.  They  also  bring  the  benefits  of 
economies  of  scale  when  implemented  through  a  nationwide  system,  thus  reducing  the  total 
cost of service delivery. Concurrently, the cost of doing business for enterprises would also be 
reduced.  Specific  examples  in  the  SDPL  include  (i)  business  licensing  and  registration 
procedures, (ii) simplified accounting system for SMEs, (iii) procedures for issuance of LURCs, 
and (iv) the uniform standardization systems.  
 
The  SDPL  also  calls  for  the  participation  of  business  representatives  in  the  SME 
98. 
Promotion Council, the highest advisory body for policy making in support of SME development, 
and  SME  representation  in  the  National  Committee  of  Standardization  and  other  relevant 
industry and technical committees for standardization. SMEs' participation is essential to ensure 
that  their  specific  competitive  disadvantages  and  unique  business  opportunities  within  the 
Vietnamese  commercial  and  industrial  environment  are  fully  considered  in  the  process  of 
formulating  policies,  rules,  and  regulations.  Their  representation  will  not  only  help  eliminate 
unfair policy bias against SMEs but also encourage transparency and stakeholder consultation 
to the benefit of the economy as a whole.

SMALL AND MEDIUM-SIZED ENTERPRISE SECTOR ANALYSIS 

A. 

Definition of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises   

Decree 90 defines SMEs to be “those business and production establishments that have 
1. 
registered  under  the  current  legislation,  have  the  registered  capital  of  less  than  D10  billion  at 
business registration agencies and/or the average number of annual permanent employees of 
less than 300.”   

B. 

Size and Diversity of the SME Sector 

2. 
Data on the SME sector in Viet Nam, as defined by Decree 90, are not collected and, as 
yet,  no  formal  request  to  collect  SME-specific  data  has  been  made  to  key  data  sources.  The 
main  sources  of  data  are  the  national  statistical  network  with  data  collected  by  the  General 
Statistical Office (GSO), and the National Business Information Network (NBIN) of the Ministry 
of Planning and Investment (MPI). Some tentative conclusions as to the size and diversity of the 
sector can be drawn, using data collected by these organizations for other purposes.  

3. 
SME  data  are  scarce  and  fragmented,  and  their  reliability  is  suspect.  There  is  a 
significant gap with respect to the availability of reliable statistical information on the registration 
and  performance  of  SMEs.  Available  data  often  aggregate  all  types  of  enterprises  including 
state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs),  non-SOEs  and  foreign  invested  enterprises.  This  makes  the 
analysis complex. Efforts have been made to disaggregate the data to the most usable extent 
possible  to  provide  a  reasonable  understanding  of  the  Vietnamese  SME  sector,  but  the 
fundamental shortcomings in the data sets used remain. 

4. 
This said, there is a consistent view that SMEs constitute an overwhelming proportion of 
total  enterprises  in  Viet  Nam;  SMEs  are  most  active  in  commerce,  trade,  repair  and 
manufacturing; and SMEs are major employment creators.   

5. 
Table A2.1 outlines the overall profile of enterprises in Viet Nam during 1998–2002. It is 
estimated that as of 31 December 2002 Viet Nam had about 736,000 registered enterprises in 
all sectors. This number does not include the several million informal household enterprises not 
obliged to register at local government offices.

direct investments to gross domestic product (GDP), and the pressing need to restructure the state-owned enterprise 
(SOE)  sector,  the  Government  now  regards  the  private  sector  as  the  main  engine  for  the  next  round  of  economic 
growth  and  employment  generation.  The  Government  expects  the  activities  of  the  private  sector,  which  consists

Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS), the private/SME sector has created and is expected to continue to create

the tax base for Viet Nam, thus increasing the opportunity for social spending. Due to the importance the Government 
places  on  developing  the  private/SME  sector  for  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction,  many  policy  actions 
supported under the SME Development Program Loan (SDPL) are also  specified in the CPRGS as requisite reform

included in the CPRGS.

Introduction

The  goal  of  the  SDPL  is  to  improve  SMEs  competitiveness  and  enhance  their  potential  contribution  to 
economic  growth  and  employment  generation,  to  enable  them  to  help  reduce  poverty  incidence  in  the  country.  The 
objective  is  to  support  the  Government  in  undertaking  measures  to  (i)  enhance  SMEs’  policy  and  regulatory 
framework,  (ii)  improve  SMEs’  access  to  key  financial  and  physical  resources,  and  (iii)  facilitate  SMEs’  access  to 
domestic and international markets. Policy conditions proposed under the SDPL are specific to achieving the Program 
objectives. Each  was reviewed in terms of its outcomes and expected  economic and social  impacts  as summarized 
below.  
 
I.   Developing an Enabling Policy and Regulatory Environment 
 

Policy  actions  proposed  for  developing  an  enabling  policy  and  regulatory  environment  for  SMEs  fall  under 
two  components:  (A)  improving  the  current  business  registration  and  licensing  systems,  and  (B)  establishing  the 
Government's  policy  and  institutional  framework  for  SME  development  through  a  coordinated  plan  based  on  public-
private  partnership.  Policy  actions  under  component  (A)  include  measures  for  simplifying  registration  and  licensing 
procedures  so  as  to  make  establishment  of  new  businesses  easier  and  encourage  businesses  to  enter  the  formal 
sector.  Such  measures  are  identified  under  the  CPRGS  as  requirements  for  poverty  reduction.  The  proposed 
computerization  of  business  registration  will  do  away  with  arbitrary  administrative  procedures,  promote  good 
governance,  reduce  transaction  costs  for  SMEs,  and  increase  accessibility.  Ex  ante  regulatory  impact  review  will 
ensure  that  unnecessary  licenses  that  discourage  SME  establishment  and  growth  are  reconsidered,  while  ex  post 
review  will  provide  feedback  to  policymakers  on  measures  adopted  for  improvement.  A  simple  and  transparent 
regulatory regime will reduce the costs for establishing businesses and complying with statutory rules and regulations, 
and help accelerate the growth of the SME sector and create new employment opportunities, including those for the 
poor. The policy actions will also support good governance and combat corruption, both acknowledged in the region 
as crucial in fighting poverty. 
 

Policy actions under component (B) supports the inclusion of private sector members to the SME Promotion 
Council to ensure that SMEs' views are better represented in policy making and program formulation. The long-term 
SME development action program to be adopted by the Government  will provide a comprehensive basis to address 
many constraints to SME development, facilitating establishment and operations of SMEs, and giving them access to 
key resources. The action program is expected to serve as a guideline for interministerial and aid coordination.  

(The Poverty Partnership Agreement was signed on 25 February 2002. Poverty incidence has declined from 37% in
1998 to 29% in 2002.)

II.   Enhancing SME's Access to Finance 
 

Enhancing  SME's  access  to  finance  has  four  components:  (A)  reducing  the  costs  and  risks  of  lending  to 
SMEs by developing an SME accounting system, (B) reducing the costs and risks of lending to SMEs by making land-
use certificates available as collateral, (C) improving SMEs' access to finance through expansion of the use of leasing, 
and  (D)  reducing  costs  and  risks  of  lending  secured  by  movable  property.  Under  component  (A),  proposed  policy 
actions  include  issuance  of  clarifications  on  Decisions  1177  and  144  on  the  Accounting  System  for  SMEs  in 
accordance with the new Accounting Law; a simplified and clear SME accounting system based on Vietnamese and 
International  Accounting  Standards;  and  the  Vietnamese  Accounting  Association  (VAA)  and  its  SME  Accounting 
Center  to  develop  a  program  to  disseminate  and  train  SMEs  and  business  associations  on  SME  accounting. 
Simplifying the accounting system will assist SME owners and managers to better plan for and manage their limited 
resources. An accounting system that is easy to understand and apply will also encourage formalization of enterprises 
and reduce costs for preparing financial statements and thereby enable SMEs to access credit from banks and other 
formal financial institutions. Accounting systems are the basis of good corporate governance and better business risk 
management.  A  simplified  accounting  system  will  support  the  establishment  and  growth  of  SMEs,  and  creation  of 
more jobs. It will also allow the Government to expand its tax base and increase social spending to aid the poor.  
 

Policy  actions  proposed  under  component  (B)  aims  to  make  the  legislative  framework  for  land  simple  and 
transparent.  It  will  benefit  SMEs  and  the  poor  alike  as  the  law  becomes  easier  to  understand  and  its  registration 
process simple and transparent. The centralized land registration system will be computerized so as to streamline the 
system  for  the  benefit  of  the  public  as  a  whole,  including  the  poor.  A  single  land  use  registry  will  ensure  clarity  and 
security of title, and improve the use of land as collateral. The cost of land registration and accessing information on 
land  will be minimum and  will be affordable to the poor. However, equipment and some technical knowledge  will be 
required  for  accessing  information  on  land.  Developing  a  functional  land  market  will  remove  distortions  and 
preferential  access  to  land.  Market-based  pricing  of  land  will  improve  valuation  for  purposes  of  collateral.  The 
economy on the whole will benefit through more efficient allocation of resources, lower transaction costs, and greater 
investment to improve sites and premises. Market-based valuation of land is likely to increase tax revenues from land 
to  enable  the  Government  to  increase  spending  on  the  poor.  A  modernized  land  management  system  by  the 
Government will further promote good governance and combat corruption, crucial in fighting poverty. 
 

Policy  actions  proposed  under  components  (C)  and  (D)  will  expand  the  use  of  leasing  and  movable 
collaterals to enable SMEs to access credit. The leasing industry, while still small in size relative to the banking sector, 
predominantly serves the SMEs by financing equipment. Policy actions support diversification of leasing products and 
sources  of  funding  for  leasing  companies.  Improved  operational  viability  of  the  leasing  sector,  and  creation  of  an 
alternative source of funding for leasing companies in particular, will help expand the coverage of leasing companies. 
Enhanced operation of the National Registry for Secured Transactions (NRAST) will, on the other hand, support the 
use  of  equipment,  inventories,  and  receivables  as  collateral  for  bank  loans,  also  aiding  SMEs  in  accessing  credit 
through  formal  financial  institutions.  Moreover,  the  economic  gains  expected  from  higher  use  of  NRAST  is  far-
reaching, as it will benefit not only the SMEs but all entities involved in extending credit backed by collateral.  
 

The  policy  actions  under  the  four  components  aim  to  resolve  SMEs  limited  access  to  finance,  long-term 
financing  in  particular,  and  thereby  promote  sustainable  growth  of  SMEs.  The  benefits  of  simple,  transparent,  and 
effective  frameworks  of  accounting,  land  registration,  leasing,  and  secured  transactions  system  will  be  felt  by  all 
enterprises. The proposed policy actions will support good governance and sustainable economic growth, and make 
positive contributions toward poverty reduction.

land-use  certificates;  (ii)  simplified  land  registration;  (iii)  requiring  information  on  land  availability  to  be  made  public; 
and (iv) promoting property market development. To support the implementation of the new Land Law, and to further

IV.  Improving SME's Access to International Markets through Enhanced Industrial and Technical Standards 
 

There are two components for improving SME's access to international markets through enhanced industrial 
and  technical  standards:  (A)  lowering  the  structural  barrier  on  industrial  and  technical  standards  for  SMEs  by 
completing the legal framework, and (B) undertaking institutional reforms and encouraging public-private partnership – 
including an information system for SMEs. Component (A) includes policy actions for: reducing regulatory compliance 
burdens on technical standards, a draft Ordinance on Technical Standardization to develop a uniform standardization 
system; enhancing public confidence in the certification institutions by requiring that any certification body operating in 
Viet Nam must be accredited by an Accreditation Body that is a mutual recognition agreement signatory member of 
the International Accreditation Forum, or Pacific Accreditation Cooperation, or by Viet Nam's Board of Accreditation; 
and  bringing  standardization  in  line  with  best  practices  by  supporting  submission  of  an  Ordinance  on  Technical 
Standardization  to  the  National  Assembly.    An  improved  standards'  framework  will  reduce  the  costs  of  compliance, 
facilitate  comparison  of  products  by  consumers,  and  generally  allow  for  better  compliance  with  standards  by 
enterprises,  including  SMEs.  Arbitrary  setting  of  standards,  which  increases  compliance  costs,  will  be  reduced  and 
application of international standards and accreditation practices will boost public confidence as well as the potential 
for  higher  exports.  The  overall  impact  will  be  enhanced  competitiveness  of  SMEs,  and  increased  opportunities  to 
access domestic, regional, and international markets. 
 

Policy  actions  under  component  (B)  include  an  on-line  database,  providing  information  to  the  SMEs  on  (i) 
national standards of other countries, international standards, and cross-recognition schemes; (ii) certification bodies, 
testing  laboratories,  and  quality  management  providers  in  Viet  Nam;  and  (iii)  relevant  information  on  technology 
transfer, legally separating Directorate for Standards and Quality’s (STAMEQ’s) commercial and state administrative 
activities  and  ensuring  SME  representation  on  the  National  Technical  Committee  of  Standardization  and  on  the 
industry technical committees of standardization for standards development. The extensive database on technical and 
industrial standards will aid the SMEs in becoming more aware of and making informed efforts toward meeting those 
standards.  This  will  facilitate  their  access  to  both  domestic  and  international  markets.  The  separation  of  commercial 
and administrative functions will improve corporate governance, increase competition, and promote public confidence 
in standards and testing. SME’s representation on the National Technical Committee and industry committees will help 
to make the standards increasingly appropriate for SMEs.  
 

The  measures  proposed  under  this  component  will  result  in  a  more  pragmatic,  efficient,  and  transparent 
process for setting standards and obtaining certifications. SMEs will benefit from reduced compliance costs and higher 
capacity  to  access  both  domestic  and  international  markets.  Increased  level  of  exports  by  SMEs  will  support  the 
viability of their long-term operations and contribute toward economic growth and poverty reduction. 
 
Conclusion 
 

The impacts of the SDPL on economic growth and employment generation are assessed to be significantly
